questions.question_text_1: A certain text document consisting of only alphanumeric characters (including spaces) takes 320000 bits, when encoded with UCS-2 encoding. How many bits will the same document take if encoded with ASCII 7-bit encoding?
question_texts: A certain text document consisting of only alphanumeric characters (including spaces) takes 320000 bits, when encoded with UCS-2 encoding. How many bits will the same document take if encoded with ASCII 7-bit encoding?

question_texts: Which of the following is true about the term “stateful” in the client-server model?

options.option_text: The server keeps the state of the client to respond to the required request.
Server is ready to respond to the client's request without knowing anythingabout the client.
Server uses various HTTP methods to respond to the client's request.
Server uses the URL to convey context to the client.

questions.question_text_1: The Quiz Master application at IITM BS allows students to attempt quizzes online. To prevent automated bots from mass-submitting quiz answers and ensure fair participation, the admin decides to implement a CAPTCHA verification system before allowing users to start a quiz. The admin decides to integrate Google reCAPTCHA into the Quiz Master app using Flask. Which Flask extension is best suited for implementing reCAPTCHA verification?
question_texts: The Quiz Master application at IITM BS allows students to attempt quizzes online. To prevent automated bots from mass-submitting quiz answers and ensure fair participation, the admin decides to implement a CAPTCHA verification system before allowing users to start a quiz. The admin decides to integrate Google reCAPTCHA into the Quiz Master app using Flask. Which Flask extension is best suited for implementing reCAPTCHA verification?

questions.question_text_1:
A mobile client starts from and is cruising away continuously at 120 kmph from the network tower whose network range is 80 km and bandwidth is 240 Mbps. How much data (in Gigabytes) will be consumed by the client who is continuously using the entire bandwidth before completely moving out of the network? 
[Take 1 Byte = 8 bits, 1 KB = 1000 Bytes, 1 MB = 1000 Kilobytes and so on.]  
[Consider the speed of light in air to be 3 x 10 8 m/sec.]

questions.question_text_1: A client machine and a server machine located 120 kilometers apart start moving towards each other along a straight line at 400 kmph and 800 kmph respectively. At the same time, the client starts sending requests to the server and the server sends back the response to the client. This client-server network continues to send requests and receive responses (with a new request being sent only after the response is received by the client for the previous one) until both the server and the client collide with each other. Calculate the total distance travelled (in kms) by the request data and the response data together before the two machines collide with each other?(assume the speed of request and response to be 3 x 108m/s )
question_texts: A client machine and a server machine located 120 kilometers apart start moving towards each other along a straight line at 400 kmph and 800 kmph respectively. At the same time, the client starts sending requests to the server and the server sends back the response to the client. This client-server network continues to send requests and receive responses (with a new request being sent only after the response is received by the client for the previous one) until both the server and the client collide with each other. Calculate the total distance travelled (in kms) by the request data and the response data together before the two machines collide with each other?(assume the speed of request and response to be 3 x 108m/s )

options.option_text: MVC allows for the implementation of multiple views of the same dataconcurrently.
MVC supports parallel development, enabling developers to work on differentparts of the application simultaneously.
MVC enforces the use of View State, increasing the bandwidth of requests.
MVC is a heavyweight framework that requires significant bandwidth due toits design.

questions.question_text_1:
A college counseling system is designed to store and retrieve student records efficiently. The system uses different types of storage based on latency, throughput, and density. During peak counseling sessions, thousands of students access their academic records, appointment schedules, and previous counseling notes. The system needs to optimize storage selection for different types of data: 
1. Frequently accessed small data (e.g., currently active student records) 2. Large archives of past counseling records (rarely accessed but need long-term storage) 3. Temporary session data that needs to be quickly read and updated during counseling sessions 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
A college counseling system is designed to store and retrieve student records efficiently. The system uses different types of storage based on latency, throughput, and density. During peak counseling sessions, thousands of students access their academic records, appointment schedules, and previous counseling notes. The system needs to optimize storage selection for different types of data: 
1. Frequently accessed small data (e.g., currently active student records) 2. Large archives of past counseling records (rarely accessed but need long-term storage) 3. Temporary session data that needs to be quickly read and updated during counseling sessions 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **"Modern Application Development I"** exam, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Encoding and Character Sets**
- **UCS-2 (Universal Character Set-2)**:
  - Uses **16 bits (2 bytes)** per character.
  - Total bits = `Number of characters × 16`.
- **ASCII (7-bit)**:
  - Uses **7 bits** per character.
  - Total bits = `Number of characters × 7`.
- **Fixed-Length Encoding**:
  - If a character set has `N` unique characters, the optimal bit length is `⌈log₂(N)⌉`.
  - Example: For `L = {13 characters}`, bits per character = `⌈log₂(13)⌉ = 4`.
  - Total characters in a file = `(File size in bytes × 8) / bits_per_character`.

**Equation**:
\[
\text{Total Characters} = \frac{\text{File Size (bytes)} \times 8}{\text{Bits per Character}}
\]

---

### **B. Client-Server Model**
- **Stateless vs. Stateful**:
  - **Stateless**: Server does not retain client state (e.g., HTTP).
  - **Stateful**: Server retains client state (e.g., WebSockets, sessions).
- **HTTP Methods**:
  - `GET`, `POST`, `PUT`, `DELETE`, etc.
- **URL vs. URI**:
  - **URL**: Specifies resource location (e.g., `https://example.com/page`).
  - **URI**: Identifies a resource (can be a URL or URN).

---

### **C. Version Control (Git)**
- **Branching & Merging**:
  - `git checkout <branch>`: Switch branches.
  - `git merge <branch>`: Merge a branch into the current branch.
- **Correct Merge Sequence**:
  ```bash
  git checkout main       # Switch to main branch
  git merge feature1      # Merge feature1 into main
  git merge feature2      # Merge feature2 into main
  ```

---

### **D. Web Security**
- **CAPTCHA**:
  - Prevents automated bots (e.g., Google reCAPTCHA).
  - **Flask-WTF** extension integrates reCAPTCHA in Flask.
- **Server-Side vs. Client-Side Validation**:
  - **Client-side**: Uses HTML5/JavaScript (not secure alone).
  - **Server-side**: Mandatory for security (e.g., Flask form validation).
- **Accessibility (WCAG Principles)**:
  - **Perceivable**: Text alternatives (`alt` tags).
  - **Operable**: Keyboard navigable.
  - **Understandable**: Clear labels (`aria-describedby`).
  - **Robust**: Compatible with assistive tech.

---

### **E. Flask & Web Development**
- **Flask Extensions**:
  - `Flask-WTF`: Form handling + CAPTCHA.
  - `Flask-SQLAlchemy`: Database ORM.
  - `Flask-RESTful`: REST API development.
- **Jinja2 Templating**:
  - Loop with conditions:
    ```jinja2
    {% for item in list if item.price < 200 and item.rating > 4 %}
      {{ item.name }}
    {% endfor %}
    ```
- **Flask Routes**:
  - Dynamic URLs: `@app.route('/score/<team>')`.
  - HTTP Methods: `@app.route('/', methods=['GET', 'POST'])`.
- **Flask Test Client**:
  - Simulate requests:
    ```python
    with app.test_request_context():
        print(url_for('user', username='John'))  # Output: /user/John
    ```

---

### **F. Databases & SQLAlchemy**
- **Relationships**:
  - **One-to-Many**:
    ```python
    class Department(db.Model):
        id = db.Column(db.Integer, primary_key=True)
        students = db.relationship('Student', backref='department')
    ```
  - **Many-to-Many**:
    - Requires an **association table**:
      ```python
      student_events = db.Table('student_events',
          db.Column('student_id', db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('student.id')),
          db.Column('event_id', db.Integer, db.ForeignKey('event.id'))
      )
      ```
- **Foreign Keys**:
  - `db.ForeignKey('department.id')` (not `faculty_id`).

---

### **G. Testing (Pytest)**
- **Fixtures**:
  ```python
  @pytest.fixture
  def students():
      return {"names": ["Alice", "Bob"], "ages": [20, 22]}
  ```
- **Selective Testing**:
  - `pytest -k "name"`: Run tests with "name" in their function name.
  - Output format:
    ```
    ======= 1 passed, 1 deselected in 0.02s =======
    ```
- **Assertions**:
  ```python
  def test_age(students):
      assert students['ages'][0] > 18
  ```

---

### **H. Networking & Data Transfer**
- **Bandwidth vs. Range**:
  - **Bandwidth (Mbps)**: Data transfer rate.
  - **Range (km)**: Coverage area of a network tower.
- **Data Consumption**:
  - If a client moves at speed `v` (km/h) away from a tower with range `R` (km) and bandwidth `B` (Mbps), total data consumed:
    \[
    \text{Data (GB)} = \frac{B \times \text{Time (hours)} \times 1000}{8 \times 1024}
    \]
    where `Time = R / v`.

---

### **I. Storage Hierarchy**
| **Storage Type**       | **Latency** | **Use Case**                          |
|------------------------|-------------|---------------------------------------|
| **Registers**          | ~1 ns       | CPU computations                      |
| **SRAM**               | ~10 ns      | Cache (fast access)                    |
| **DRAM**               | ~100 ns     | Main memory (RAM)                     |
| **SSD**                | ~100 µs     | Fast storage (OS, apps)               |
| **HDD**                | ~10 ms      | Archival storage (cheap, high density) |

---

### **J. MVC Architecture**
- **Model-View-Controller**:
  - **Model**: Business logic (e.g., database).
  - **View**: UI (e.g., HTML templates).
  - **Controller**: Handles requests (e.g., Flask routes).
- **Benefits**:
  - Separation of concerns.
  - Parallel development (frontend/backend).
  - Multiple views for the same data.

---

### **K. Web Servers (Apache vs. Nginx)**
| **Feature**            | **Apache**                          | **Nginx**                          |
|------------------------|-------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| **Concurrency**        | Process/thread-based (slower)       | Event-driven (faster)               |
| **Static Files**       | Slower                              | Faster (optimized)                  |
| **Dynamic Content**   | Modular (`.htaccess`)               | Reverse proxy (e.g., FastCGI)       |
| **Use Case**           | Traditional LAMP stack              | High-traffic sites (Netflix, Dropbox)|

---

### **L. JavaScript & DOM Manipulation**
- **Bold Text in Input Field**:
  ```javascript
  document.getElementById("txt1").style.fontWeight = "bold";
  ```
- **Event Handling**:
  ```html
  <input type="button" onclick="doSomething()" value="Click me!">
  ```

---

### **M. RESTful APIs (Flask-RESTful)**
- **HTTP Methods**:
  - `GET /resource`: Retrieve data.
  - `POST /resource`: Create data.
  - `PUT /resource/<id>`: Update data.
  - `DELETE /resource/<id>`: Delete data.
- **Error Handling**:
  - `404`: Resource not found.
  - `400`: Bad request (e.g., missing `student_id` in POST).

---

## **2. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Encoding & Character Sets**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Text Document] --> B[Encoding Scheme]
    B --> C[UCS-2: 16 bits/char]
    B --> D[ASCII: 7 bits/char]
    C --> E["Total Bits = Chars × 16"]
    D --> F["Total Bits = Chars × 7"]
```

### **Graph 2: Client-Server Model**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Client] -->|Request| B[Server]
    B -->|Stateful| C[Retains Client State]
    B -->|Stateless| D[No Client State]
    C --> E[Sessions, WebSockets]
    D --> F[HTTP, REST APIs]
```

### **Graph 3: Git Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[main] -->|git checkout| B[feature1]
    A -->|git checkout| C[feature2]
    B -->|git merge| A
    C -->|git merge| A
```

### **Graph 4: Flask Route Handling**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Flask App] --> B[/@app.route('/')]
    A --> C[/@app.route('/score/<team>')]
    A --> D[/@app.route('/score/<team>/<player>')]
    B --> E["Returns: Welcome Message"]
    C --> F["Returns: Team Score"]
    D --> G["Returns: Player Score"]
```

### **Graph 5: Database Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Student] -->|Many-to-One| B[Department]
    A -->|Many-to-Many| C[Event]
    C -->|Association Table| A
```

### **Graph 6: Storage Hierarchy**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Fastest] --> B[Registers]
    B --> C[SRAM]
    C --> D[DRAM]
    D --> E[SSD]
    E --> F[HDD]
    F --> G[Slowest]
```

### **Graph 7: MVC Architecture**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Model: Data] --> B[View: UI]
    B --> C[Controller: Logic]
    C --> A
```

### **Graph 8: HTTP Methods in REST**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[GET] --> B[Retrieve Data]
    C[POST] --> D[Create Data]
    E[PUT] --> F[Update Data]
    G[DELETE] --> H[Delete Data]
```

---
## **3. Key Equations (Math-Related)**
1. **UCS-2 to ASCII Conversion**:
   \[
   \text{ASCII Bits} = \text{UCS-2 Bits} \times \frac{7}{16}
   \]
2. **Fixed-Length Encoding**:
   \[
   \text{Bits per Character} = \lceil \log_2(\text{Character Set Size}) \rceil
   \]
3. **Data Consumption in Network**:
   \[
   \text{Time} = \frac{\text{Range}}{\text{Speed}}, \quad \text{Data (GB)} = \frac{\text{Bandwidth (Mbps)} \times \text{Time (hrs)} \times 1000}{8 \times 1024}
   \]
4. **Relative Speed of Machines**:
   \[
   \text{Time to Collision} = \frac{\text{Distance}}{\text{Relative Speed}}
   \]
   \[
   \text{Data Transferred} = \text{Bandwidth} \times \text{Time}
   \]
